practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: I need to get comfortable with the request-response cycle. I will focus on making sure I can route various URLs to specific functions and return simple HTML templates without worrying about databases yet.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Building small multi-route applications using static Jinja2 templates.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Mapping HTTP methods (GET, POST) to specific route handlers.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Returning simple strings or static HTML files from a route.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Capturing dynamic URL parameters and using them to change template logic.

objective: Create a 5-page static site with navigation.
Pass at least 3 types of dynamic data to a template.
subjective: Feeling confident that I know where to look when a 404 error occurs.
Sense of ease when organizing template folders.

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: Now I will introduce SQLAlchemy. The goal is to move from static data to a database. I'll spend my time learning how to create models and run queries so the app actually remembers things.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Implementing CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations for a single resource (e.g., a Todo list or a Blog).
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Managing database migrations using Flask-Migrate when I change my data models.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Querying all records and displaying them in a list.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Setting up one-to-many relationships between different data tables.

objective: Build a functional app where data persists after a server restart.
Successfully run a migration to add a new column to an existing table.
subjective: Reduced anxiety when viewing database connection errors.
Understanding the flow of data from a form to the database.

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: I'll start looking at how to make the app more robust by adding user authentication and custom error handling. This is where I move from 'it works' to 'it's a real application'.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Integrating Flask-Login for session management and securing specific routes.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Refactoring code into Blueprints to keep the project organized as it grows.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Protecting a route so only 'logged in' users can see it.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Implementing custom error pages and flash messaging for better user feedback.

objective: A project restructured into Blueprints with a working login system.
Zero manual database manipulation; all changes handled via scripts.
subjective: Clarity in how to structure a large-scale Flask application.
Ability to read Flask extension documentation and implement features without tutorials.

objective: Number of unique Flask extensions successfully integrated.
Lines of code refactored into reusable Blueprints.
Time taken to implement a new feature from scratch (e.g., a search bar).
subjective: Self-rated level of 'lostness' when looking at the official Flask documentation.
Level of comfort with Python's 'decorator' syntax used in Flask routes.
The ability to explain the Flask request context to someone else.

architect_notes: I kept the weekly hours at 5, which means progress will feel slow but steady. I'm focusing on one major concept per cycle to prevent burnout.
I'm assuming a basic knowledge of Python; if I struggle with lists or dictionaries, I'll need to pause and review those outside these 5 hours.
The switch to Blueprints in Cycle 3 is a key 'intermediate' milestone that separates beginners from practitioners.

details.reason: User initiated a new learning session.

timeline.title: Initial Practice Strategy Created
timeline.summary: Initial practice strategy created for ['Learn Python Flask'].

details.reason: Sufficient information provided to create initial practice system.

constraints.dropout_risk: Cognitive load from concurrent database and front-end management
